Title: Michael Moriarty Named CFO of Disney's Experiences Division
Description:
Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter

Moriarty will succeed Kevin Lansberry, who is retiring after 39 years with the company.


							By 

	Alex Weprin


Senior Editor


	The Walt Disney Co. is making a significant change in the C-suite of its experiences division, which oversees the company's theme parks, cruise line and consumer products businesses.


	Kevin Lansberry, the CFO of Disney Experiences, will be retiring after 39 years with the company in February. Michael Moriarty, currently President and managing director of Hong Kong Disneyland Resort, will succeed him as executive VP and CFO of the division, which is led by chairman Josh D'Amaro.




	â€œMichael Moriarty brings a deep understanding of our long-term strategy to broaden the reach and impact of Disney Experiences,â€ said D'Amaro in a statement. â€œHis global perspective and leadership will help guide us through an exciting chapter of growth, reaching new fans in new places and on new platforms.â€ 

	











	Before leading Hong Kong Disneyland, Moriarty was CFO of that theme park, and also worked as CFO at Walt Disney Imagineering, and in senior finance roles at Walt Disney World. The company will name his successor at Hong Kong Disneyland at a later date.


	Lansberry, meanwhile, served in a wide array of roles at the company during his career, including a stint as interim CFO of Disney after the exit of Christine McCarthy in 2023. Hugh Johnston joined Disney later that year as its permanent CEO, at which point Lansberry returned to the Experiences division.

Title: 'Bosch' Prequel Series 'Start Of Watch' Greenlighted By MGM+
Description:
By Nellie Andreeva 

Co-Editor-in-Chief, TV


	The Bosch universe at Amazon continues to expand with a prequel series for MGM+, Bosch: Start of Watch, starring Cameron Monaghan (Shameless) and Omari Hardwick (Power). The premium linear channel and streaming service has greenlighted the offshoot which explores the origin story of Michael Connelly's detective Harry Bosch, portrayed by Titus Welliver on the original Bosch series and its sequel Bosch: Legacy. 


	Monaghan will take over the role, playing rookie cop Harry Bosch, with Hardwick portraying his training officer, police veteran Eli Bridges, a new character not in the book mythology. There is no direct source material for Start of Watch since Connelly's novels do not include a Bosch prequel, though bits and pieces from Harry's early years are planted in various books in the universe, with Connelly calling the prequel â€œuncharted character territory.â€

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	Casting
	



	
		
					Kat Cunning Joins MGM+'s 'American Hostage' As Recurring		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Tavon Olds-Sample, Reggie Lochard & Anika Noni Rose Attached To Coming-Of-Age Drama 'Shadow Dance'		
			








Bosch: Start of Watch, from MGM+ Studios, goes back to 1991 Los Angeles and follows 26-year-old Harry Bosch (Monaghan) during his earliest days as a rookie cop. The series will explore a city on the edge, teeming with racial tension, gang violence, and a fractured LAPD. Amid routine calls and growing unrest, Bosch finds himself drawn into a high-profile heist and a web of criminal corruption that will test his loyalty to the badge and shape his future as the detective who lives by the code, â€œEverybody counts or nobody counts.â€




			Watch on Deadline		







	Produced by Fabel Entertainment, the series is co-created and executive produced by Bosch: Legacy co-developer/executive producer Tom Bernardo and Legacy co-executive producer Brian Anthony, with Bernardo serving as showrunner. Connelly, Henrik Bastin, Jamie Boscardin Martin, and Jasmine Russ also serve as executive producers. Theresa Snider co-executive produces for Hieronymus Pictures. Seth Yanklewitz is the casting director.

	











	Like all previous series in the franchise, Bosch, Bosch: Legacy and spinoff Ballard starring Maggie Q, which was just renewed for Season 2 by Prime Video, Bosch: Start of Watch will film in Los Angeles where the books are set. The prequel recently received a tax credit from the California Film Commission alongside Ballard S2. Submitted as â€œProject 2997 S1,â€ Start of Watch landed $11.6M credit on $33.2M qualified local expenditures.


	â€œWe are thrilled to expand the Bosch universe with this compelling origin story that showcases how one of television's most beloved detectives became the man we know today,â€ said Michael Wright, head of MGM+. â€œWith Cameron Monaghan and Omari Hardwick bringing these complex characters to life, and the creative vision of Michael Connelly and our talented executive producers, Bosch: Start of Watch promises to deliver the gritty, authentic storytelling that honors the franchise's legacy while opening an exciting new chapter.â€


	This marks the fourth series in the Bosch franchise and third centered on Harry Bosch. All three originated on different Amazon platforms. The mothership Bosch, the longest running series on Prime Video, released seven seasons on the flagship streamer. Sequel Bosch: Legacy, which ran for three seasons, started on Amazon Freevee before migrating to Prime Video. Bosch: Start of Watch is headed to MGM+.


	â€œI'm deeply grateful to Michael Wright and the team at MGM+ for championing this next chapter in Bosch's journey with such remarkable care and integrity,â€ Connelly said. â€œBeing able to see how Harry Bosch became the man we have loved for 10 seasons is a gift to me and his many fans. I can't wait to dig in with Cameron and the writers to explore this uncharted character territory.â€


	In Start of Watch, Harry Bosch (Monaghan), a intensely observant, stoic and unyielding young man, is a probationary patrol officer with the LAPD. He possesses all the qualities that will come to mark his legendary career: he's smart, relentless, determined, fiercely protective of the victims of crime.


	Training Officer Bridges (Hardwick) is a Vietnam vet, a seasoned, salty, rough-around-the-edges kind of cop who mentors Harry through the mean streets of Los Angeles and the complicated world of the LAPD. Bridges is fighting a war on the streets and looking for soldiers, and they don't come any brighter than Hieronymus Bosch.


	â€œIt's a terrific privilege to be able to explore both the origins of this iconic character and the Los Angeles that formed him in the early 1990s,â€ Bernardo said. â€œIn telling the story of a young Harry Bosch, we want to honor the faith of Michael Connelly's legion of readers and the amazing audience that tuned into Bosch and Bosch: Legacy over the years. We're excited to embark on this journey.â€


	In taking the prequel series route, Bosch follows in the footsteps of such crime dramas as CBS' NCIS (with NCIS: Origins) and Showtime's Dexter (with Dexter: Original Sin). 


	Bastin called the opportunity to film Bosch: Start of Watch in Los Angeles â€œa rare privilege these days.â€


	â€œBy filming in LA, we'll be able to tap into the best creative talent this industry has to offer â€” and in doing so deliver a story about Harry Bosch that fans have longed for,â€ he said. â€œThanks to MGM+ for giving us the resources to make it happen, and to the California Tax Credit for bringing business back to LA!â€


Bosch: Start of Watch, part of MGM+'s programming focus on classic Hollywood storytelling for a modern audience, will be available on the platform in the U.S., UK, Italy, Germany, Spain, Latin America, Belgium, and the Netherlands.

	











	Monaghan is probably best known for his decade-long portrayal of Ian Gallagher on Showtime's popular series Shameless, which earned him a Critics Choice Award nomination. He also played the Valeska twins on Fox's Gotham. In features, he is currently seen in Tron: Ares. Monaghan is repped by UTA, Amplified, and Goodman Genow Schenkman, Smelkinson & Christopher. . 


	Hardwick is known for his starring role as James â€œGhostâ€ St. Patrick on Starz's hit series Power and for portraying Vanderohe in Zack Snyder's Army of the Dead. He recently starred opposite Michelle Yeoh in Paramount+'s Star Trek: Section 31. Hardwick is repped by UTA and Sloane, Offer, Weber, and Dern


	Bernardo, a Bosch franchise veteran who worked on the mothership series before segueing to Legacy and also did a stint on Netflix's Lincoln Lawyer, is repped by Verve and Hansen Jacobson Teller.

Title: â€˜It Gets Worse': Host Of Names Joining A24's Comedy Series For Channel 4 As Cameras Roll; First-Look Image
Description:
By Jesse Whittock 

International TV Co-Editor


EXCLUSIVE: Cameras are rolling on Leo Reichâ€˜s Channel 4 flatshare comedy series It Gets Worse, and we can reveal a host of acting talent now attached.


	The UK series which A24 is producing for Channel 4 and has Bell Media-owned Crave onboard as a buyer, has attached Emily Fairn (House of Guinness, The Responder) and Olive Gray (Save Me, Halo) as Reich's co-stars, with Sean Delaney (Killing Eve, Life After Life), Dane Williams (What It Feels Like for A Girl, House of David), India Mullen (Normal People, Brassic) and Edinburgh Comedy Award 2025 nominee John Tothill also attached.





	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Norman Reedus & Melissa McBride Talk Daryl & Carol's Journey In 'The Walking Dead' - MIPCOM		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Fremantle Boards Punk Rock Feature Doc 'Billy Idol Should Be Dead'		
			








	Intriguingly, among further castings are Lena Dunham (Good Sex, Too Much) and Chicken Shop Dates host Amelia Dimoldenberg. No word on their roles in the show, which Reich stars in as well as writing and creating.

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	Also cast are Andrew Scott (All of Us Strangers, Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery), Arian Nik (Daddy Issues, Film Club), Safia Oakley-Green (The Bluff, Out of Darkness), Blake Harrison (Bookish, I Hate Suzie), Nicole Sadie Sawyerr (Casualty, Twenty Twenty Six), Phil Zimmerman (Silent Witness, Dumbo), Billy Rilot (Robin Hood, The Undeclared War), Kirsty Bloom (Sex Education, Supacell), musician and performance artist Babymorocco Clayton Pettet, Luca Kamleh-Chapman (Words of War, The Gathering), Vicki Pepperdine (Poor Things, The Windsors), and Emmeline Downie.


	The show follows Ethan, Abi, and Sam, who are best friends from uni, soulmates for life, and dysfunctional roommates. Per the synopsis: â€œIt's been a year since they finally managed to move to London, they have collectively accomplished nothing, and now their landlord is selling up. They're getting kicked out. What now? Can they keep their friendships alive when they are dispersed across a city that seems to want them dead? Can they find a six out of ten or higher to have bad sex with? Can they get their shit together when the world is so obviously falling apart? Probably not. But they're going to have fun trying.â€

	











	Charlie Perkins, Channel 4's Head of Comedy originally commissioned the show, with streamer Crave boarding to take Canadian rights. A24 is making the show, Sam Pinnell (Trying, Motherland) the producer and Mounia Akl (House of Guinness, The Responder) directing. Emmy winner Matthew Lewis (Adolescence) is the DoP on the six-part show, which will launch on TV and streaming .

Title: Ego Nwodim Lands First Gig Following â€˜SNL' Exit & Joins â€˜The Comedy Series' Lineup
Description:
By Armando Tinoco 

Staff Writer


Ego Nwodim has landed her first show following her exit from Saturday Night Live.


	The stand-up comedian will perform at Lincoln Center Theater's Claire Tow Theater in New York City. The show will run from November 19 through November 23, with tickets going on sale on October 20 at 10 a.m. ET.


	Nwodim's show will be part of The Comedy Series programming, which will also feature Vir Das, Jerrod Carmichael, and Sam Jay. The series is described as â€œa chance for these artists to test boundaries, shape new material, and explore the space between humor and truth.â€


	â€œNo two performances will be the sameâ€”because the creative process isn't a straight line, and neither is this show. It's comedy that's evolving before your eyes,â€ reads the press release.

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	Although Nwodim was expected to return to SNL Season 51, she announced her exit from the NBC late-night show after being part of the cast for seven seasons.


RELATED: â€˜Saturday Night Live': List Of All Cast Members Not Returning For â€˜SNL' Season 51 On NBC


	â€œThe hardest part of a great party is knowing when to say goodnight,â€ she wrote in an Instagram post confirming her departure. â€œBut after seven unforgettable seasons, I have decided to leave SNL. I am immensely grateful to Lorne [Michaels] for the opportunity, to my castmates, the writers, and the crew for their brilliance, support, and friendship. Week after week on that stage taught me more than I could have ever imagined, and I will carry those memories, and that laughter, with me always.â€

A post shared by Ego Nwodim (@eggyboom)

Title: Cult Of Criterion: Altered States
Description:
In Cult Of Criterion, The A.V. Club highlights a new release from The Criterion Collection each month, examining the films entering an increasingly accessible film canon.

When I started this column a year ago, I wanted to follow in the footsteps of some of my A.V. Club predecessors who helped highlight smaller, odder films that deserve to be remembered by those dipping their toes into cinephilia. At the same time, the series is an acknowledgement of The Criterion Collection (and its streaming service The Criterion Channel) as a modern establishment, one with the same kind of inviting, taken-with-a-grain-of-salt curation as some of the form's long-standing guide textsâ€”the Sight & Sound polls or 1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die or Roger Ebert's Great Movies or A Personal Journey With Martin Scorsese Through American Moviesâ€”and the same kind of surprising strangeness you might once have found browsing a video store's shelves, steered solely by vibes. Those films that split the difference between the canonized and the cuckoo are special. One of them, Masahiro Shinoda's Demon Pond, kicked off Cult Of Criterion last October. Now another, Ken Russell's Altered States, rings in its anniversary.

At first blush, the British oddball's first Hollywood film offers a wealth of respectable bonafides. William Hurt plays the lead in his debut role, fresh from the post-Juilliard stage. Paddy Chayefsky, one of the few screenwriters some people actually know by name, adapted his own novel for the script (before taking his name off the project). John Corigliano, who had just won a Guggenheim fellowship, was nominated for an Oscar for his first film score. Warner Bros. put the film out into theaters on Christmas. And yet, thanks to Russellâ€”whose baroque work includes The Devils and The Lair Of The White Wormâ€”it's all in service of a complete head trip, a seriously unserious turn-of-the-'80s reckoning with the countercultural self-experimentation of psychonauts like John C. Lilly. 

This contradiction is echoed in the text of the film: A tenured Harvard psychopathologist's woo-woo tendencies are brushed off by those who can't help but acknowledge his brilliance. For every blistering diatribe about truth and God, sometimes in the middle of a sex scene, there is a ridiculously brash image that pierces its academic veneer, like a seven-eyed goat Christ or a trippy tea-time. As the professor finds himself drawn again and again towards hallucinating in a sensory deprivation tank, his mindâ€”and, eventually, bodyâ€”unravels away from his colleagues and loved ones.

The subsequent sci-fi body horror, courtesy of makeup wizard Dick Smith and Chayefsky's earnest script, is a bit like Russell doing David Cronenberg. Released just one month before Scanners, Altered States is similarly devoted to dry, institutional dweebs justifying their doomed, id-driven experiments with endless jargon until the faÃ§ade bursts and wet, goopy truth breaks free.

But even removed from the era-specific observations around trendy, intellectualized drug use, Altered States contains unflattering universal truths. One doesn't have to be well-versed in the history of psilocybinâ€”appropriated in America after a couple enthusiasts convinced an Indigenous Mexican shaman to let them participate in a traditional religious ceremony, then blew up her spot in Life magazineâ€”to appreciate the plot points and arcs typical to white guys with no real problems ruining their lives. 

The passions of Eddie Jessup (Hurt) are balanced by two excellent colleaguesâ€”Bob Balaban as his moony tripsitter and Charles Haid as his frustrated Southern naysayerâ€”and his hyper-rational anthropologist wife (Blair Brown), all sticking by his side despite his diminishing grasp on reality. Decades later, the film evokes the contemporary, myopic, smug self-assurance of alternative medicine types, of supplement grifters, of ayahuasca ceremonies turned into tourist traps. In Altered Statesâ€˜ Eddie, one sees a familiar kind of man: A man fleeing the world in front of him, and, to save his ego, reframing this retreat as a pursuit, one of a greater wisdom that exists outside of convention. This is Aaron Rodgers if he took so many drugs that he monkeyfied himself.

Yes, Eddie's physical reversion into a more primate-like form is just one ridiculous element of a film that takes what initially seems like a one-sided, Prince Of Darkness-like battle between science and religion, and turns it into a silly-sweet episode of The X-Files where a goofy creature runs amok and love saves the day. It's also not the only nutty prosthetic Smith crafts for Altered States. In any given frame, Eddie could look totally normal, like a Geico caveman, or like the worm-headed Bib Fortuna from Star Wars (you know, the guy who's coworkers with Salacious Crumb).

These are just the most physical ways that Russell manifests the hopes and fears of a generation of mind-expanders. In garish montages, Russell sticks his protagonist in a Peter Gabriel music video, obliterates his body like one of Pompeii's ash-frozen corpses, and torments him with silent-movie visions of epic religious horrors. More abstract are the colorful explosions that resemble both stars and cells, vibrating with the fervor of French documentarian Jean PainlevÃ©.

This description may lead one to believe that Altered States is a movie that naturally welcomes a high viewing experience. But I cannot emphasize enough how little this movie made me want to do drugs. Russell's film is a series of bad trips burned from the brain onto celluloidâ€”it is a panicky, out-of-control, irrational subconscious attacking the thinking brain in every frame. These are the just deserts earned by Eddie's ravenous, avoidant appetite for discovery. 

What really matters for Eddie, in the end, is what he's been running from all along: His family, his friends, and simple human love. It's completely cheesy, or at least it would be if not for the vital, personal danger injected into this lesson by Russell and Chayefsky. This collision between two opposing auteurs (who, by all accounts, despised each other) still boasted a shared villain, normalcy, that it fought with a shared weapon, professional obsession. Altered Statesâ€˜ conclusion, sincere and relatable compared to the heightened mania leading up to it, is one of acceptance. As bizarre as the film gets, and as outrÃ© as its filmmaker and main character like to think of themselves as, the undeniable revelation sought by its fringe-dweller is the same as the one found in hackneyed romancesâ€”sometimes you just need to turn yourself into the universe's throbbing fetus before you realize that we find our answers in each other.

Title: Daniel Day-Lewis insists Method acting isn't a "cult," says critics just don't get it
Description:
Famed Method actor Daniel Day-Lewis doesn't think the technique deserves the bad rap it's gotten over the past few years. He also swears he's not in a cult. (Hear that, Brian Cox?) â€œAll the recent commentary in the last few years about Method acting is invariably from people who have little or no understanding of what it actually involves,â€ the Oscar winner said during a conversation at the BFI London Film Festival, per Variety. â€œIt's almost as if it's some specious science that we're involved in, or a cult. But it's just a way of freeing yourself so that the spontaneity, when you are working with your colleagues in front of the camera, that you are free to respond in any way that you'll move to in that moment.â€

However you feel about the immersive, somewhat controversial technique, it's clearly worked for Day-Lewis. He's won three Best Actor Oscars throughout his career (for My Left Foot, There Will Be Blood, and Lincoln) and has been nominated for three more. Some such as actor David Harbour have even held him up as a rare exception to their personal philosophy that Method acting is mostly just madness. To Day-Lewis, on the other hand, it's really quite simple. â€œIt's very easy to describe what I do as if I'm out of my mind. Plenty of people have been happy to do that, but it just makes sense to me,â€ he said. â€œYou have an obligation to try to understand as far as you're humanly able to what it feels like to be inside of that experience.â€ The actor also pushed back against the claim that immersing yourself in a role means â€œyou're sealed off from experiencingâ€ your own life. It actually means â€œyou're in a self-contained experience of your own,â€ he said. â€œBut really, if you've done your work, you should be free to accept whatever passes through you.â€ 

The acclaimed actor recently ended his â€œretirementâ€ to co-write and star in his son Ronan Day-Lewis' directorial debut, Anemone. In the film, he â€œunsurprisinglyâ€¦ delivers every line with masterful, lived-in magnetism,â€ as Luke Hicks wrote in his review of the surreal project for The A.V. Club. Ronan had never experienced his father's techniques from behind the camera before, but backed up his claim that immersion in a character doesn't mean you're fully cut off from the reality of the world around you. In a recent interview with The A.V. Club, the younger Day-Lewis said he wasn't expecting how â€œcollaborative [Daniel] was able to be on set, despite how fully enmeshed in his character he was.â€ He added, â€œThat was amazing to see and very reassuring early on in the shoot.â€

Title: DWTS Contestant Reveals on Live TV That They're Having a Baby
Description:
It was a heartwarming and unforgettable night on â€œDancing With the Starsâ€œ. Pentatonix singer Scott Hoying moved viewers to tears with a deeply personal performance, and a joyful announcement that left the ballroom cheering.

During Week 5's â€œDedication Night,â€ the 32-year-old artist dedicated his foxtrot to his husband, Mark, dancing alongside pro partner Rylee Arnold to his own original song, â€œParallel.â€ The emotional track was inspired by the night he and Mark first fell in love, staying up talking until sunrise.

â€œI am so in love with him, and I have been hoping we would make it to this week,â€ Hoying shared in rehearsal. â€œI've always been a workaholic. We toured every single year. I felt like I was always dating mean guys. When I met Mark, it felt like I could exhale. I could be myself.â€

A post shared by Scott Hoying (@scotthoying)

The Grammy-winning artist opened up about how his husband helped him heal and grow. â€œWhat happens is your self-esteem starts to heal, and that starts to trickle into all areas of your life,â€ Hoying said. â€œHe's so special.â€

Their heartfelt foxtrot beautifully reflected their love story, with Hoying's vocals and emotional movement creating one of the night's standout moments.

A post shared by Scott Hoying (@scotthoying)

In a tender backstage moment that aired during the show, Scott and Mark shared exciting personal news with Rylee, and with millions of viewers watching at home.

â€œWe're gonna be dads,â€ the couple announced, smiling through tears. â€œOur surrogate is pregnant!â€

Mark added, â€œWe've dreamed of this our whole lives. Scott's gonna be the best dad in the whole world.â€ He also shared how meaningful Scott's dedication was to him, saying, â€œFor him to dedicate this performance, to a song he wrote about our love, I will treasure this for the rest of my life.â€

Scott and Mark's love story began in 2017 and reached a new chapter in 2023 when they exchanged vows in a romantic ceremony officiated by singer Christina Perri. Their wedding, filled with music, laughter, and heartfelt emotion, reflected the same warmth and connection that now defines their journey into parenthood.

Their joyful baby announcement on Dancing With the Stars became one of the most talked-about moments of the evening, as fans flooded social media with love, congratulations, and tears of happiness.

It was a night to remember, a beautiful celebration of love, artistry, and new beginnings, as Scott Hoying filled the ballroom with both heart and harmony.

Title: 'Southern Charm's' Olivia Flowers' Bachelorette Party Photos
Description:
Bravo fans love to see their favorite reality TV stars celebrating huge life moments, including seeing how they spend their fun-filled bachelorette getaways before tying the knot.

Former â€œSouthern Charmâ€ star Olivia Flowers recently shared photos and videos on Instagram of her Bachelorette party, or, more like, an extravaganza in Miami, Florida. Sharing the special occasion with her closest friends, Flowers appeared to have the best time before she weds her fiancÃ©, Alex Williams.

A post shared by Olivia Flowers (@oliviabflowers)

Olivia Flowers, who appeared on seasons 8 and 9 of Bravo's â€œSouthern Charm,â€ recently celebrated her bachelorette party in Miami. She shared several photos and videos from the getaway, including the house where she and her friends stayed, having a lively pool party, and a night out on the town where the women danced the night away. 

A post shared by Olivia Flowers (@oliviabflowers)

To kick off her bachelorette, Flowers' friends set up a beautiful display of white and gold balloons with one that read â€œBrideâ€ above her bed. Flowers' bachelorette weekend getaway consisted of her and her friends taking a pilates class outside their rented home, and a pool party, catered by the sauce company, Saucy Gourment. Flowers' abs were on full display as she wore a white bikini and a long lace cover-up.

During another night, Flowers and her gal pals headed to KiKi on the River, a waterfront Mediterranean restaurant in Miami, where they dined and danced. Flowers was given a bridal crown and a heart-shaped cake that unveiled a photo of her and her fiancÃ©, Alex Williams, when lit.

A post shared by Caroline Grace McDonald (@caro1grace)

In an Oct. 1 post, the reality star shared how thankful she was to have her closest friends celebrate with her. â€œSome of you I met in elementary school, others we survived high school awkward phases and questionable first loves, then there are my college sweethearts who I can't imagine life withoutâ€¦ You've been with me through every chapter. Yall are my favorite blessing. Cheers to many more milestones together.â€

Fans didn't see any of Flowers' â€œSouthern Charmâ€ co-stars at her bachelorette party, but it didn't mean that she wasn't going to invite a few of them to her upcoming wedding. 

Speaking with Page Six's â€œVirtual Reali-Tea,â€ Flowers revealed that Venita Aspen, Leva Bonaparte, and her husband, Lamar Bonaparte, scored invites. 

â€œLeva and Lamar, they're close family friends, and I would love to have them there,â€ she told the outlet. â€œI think we just want to keep it to the close-knit peopleâ€¦[and] Venita. That would be it.â€

As fans may remember, Flowers had a major falling out with former friend Taylor Ann Green after Green revealed she had kissed Flowers' ex, Austen Kroll. Flowers wasn't asked to return to the show after season 9, which she said left her completely â€œblindsidedâ€ during an appearance on an episode of â€œScheananigans with Scheana Shay.â€

Flowers got engaged to Williams in New York City in September 2024. According to Page Six, the couple will be getting married in Texas this November.

Title: Lacey Chabert Debuts Her Hallmark Christmas Product Line: SEE IT
Description:
Having just wrapped filming on her 44th Hallmark movie, including starring in more Hallmark Christmas movies than anyone on planet earth, Lacey Chabert is delivering an extra dose of holiday cheer in 2025. 

As part of a â€œover-archingâ€ deal with Hallmark that was announced in February, the rom-com queen and star of Hallmark's heartwarming unscripted series â€œCelebrations with Lacey Chabertâ€ partnered with Hallmark designers and cardmakers to develop her first-ever line of Christmas decor and wrapping. 

A post shared by Hallmark Gold Crown Stores (@hallmarkstores)

Chabert has provided glimpses of her new product line, illustrated with a vintage-inspired holiday vibe, during the second season of â€œCelebrations,â€ airing Monday nights on Hallmark Channel. 

In scenes shared by Hallmark Gold Crown Stores' social media account, as seen above, she's seen wrapping a gift in one of her 10 colorful rolls of wrapping paper, which all have a retro feel. Several are reversible, with festive designs on both sides of the paper. 

In another scene from a recent episode of â€œCelebrations,â€ in which Chabert and her event planning team throw surprise parties for people who've made a difference in their communities, they serve cookies on her gold serving tray with handles (available for $45.99), featuring illustrated pink and red poinsettias and a mint-colored bow on a forest green background. 

Other items in Chabert's collection include a set of four coordinating dessert plates for $25.99, six assorted round, glass ornaments for $45.99, a darling box with 24 blank holiday cards inside for $15.99, a trio of ceramic bowls in red, white, and green for $28.99, and a set of two low-ball glasses with her signature ribbon decorations for $33.99. 

Hallmark Channel fans' favorite item, though, might be Chabert's set of four festive popcorn bowls with messages like â€œMore Snacks, More Merry, More Hallmark Channelâ€ for $33.99. 

Meanwhile, for the most die-hard fans of Hallmark's queen of Christmas, there's also a porcelain Lacey Chabert ornament, with her dressed in a sleeveless red gown, for $26.99. 

After the holidays, the Lacey Chabert Collection will expand in 2026, according to the original announcement, which said the actress will continue to help design â€œeveryday products that help people create joyful memories year-round.â€

A post shared by Hallmark (@hallmark)

Chabert is among the many Hallmark stars descending on Nashville this week to kick off Countdown to Christmas 2025 with appearances and a party at the Grand Ole Opry. On October 14, Nikki DeLoach shared a photo in her Instagram Stories of herself on a plane with Chabert, Sharon Lawrence, and Eliza Hayes Maher before they took off for Music City. 

On October 15, Chabert will be at the Little Green Apple gift store (also known as Amy's Hallmark) from 10 a.m. to noon local time in nearby Franklin, along with fellow Hallmark stars Ashley Williams, Benjamin Ayres, B.J. Britt, and Brooke D'Orsay. Fans will have the chance to purchase signed items from Chabert's new collection, per the store. 

Other stars will be at Katy's Hallmark in Nashville at the same time â€” fans can meet up with Andrew Walker, Kimberley Sustad, Paul Campbell, Rachel Boston, and Tyler Hynes.

Title: Will HGTV's 'Unsellable Houses' Ever Return? Lyndsay Lamb Finally Responds to Fans' Questions
Description:
Amid a whirlwind of shocking series cancellations at HGTV during the summer of 2025 and news of new series in the works, twin sisters Lyndsay Lamb and Leslie Davis have been noticeably quiet about the future of their show, â€œUnsellable Houses.â€

The duo remains active on social media, still running and promoting their Lamb & Co. real estate, design, and decor businesses in Snohomish, Washington. Now, one year after their show's fifth season debuted in the fall of 2024, one of the sisters has finally begun to acknowledge fans' questions about their on-air future. 

Throughout the summer, many of Davis and Lamb's HGTV peers made headlines as they revealed their shows were not renewed for new seasons, including Jonathan Knight's â€œFixer to Fabulous,â€ Egypt Sherrod and Mike Jackson's â€œMarried to Real Estate,â€ and â€œBargain Blockâ€ with Keith Bynum and Evan Thomas. 

Meanwhile, in late August, HGTV announced a full slate of new and returning shows for the end of 2025 and early 2026 â€” but â€œUnsellable Housesâ€ wasn't on the list. 

For months, when fans peppered Davis and Lamb's social media posts with questions about their show's future, the duo typically ignored the inquiries. But in early October 2025, Lamb has acknowledged some of her Instagram followers' comments about wanting to see the show return. 

On an Instagram video she posted on October 3 about creative tabletop ideas for hosting a fall meal, she replied to a fan who commented, â€œBeautiful! Miss seeing you and your sissy on TV -ğŸ˜”, hope you two have another show brewing !!!!â€ Lamb's reply? â€œAlways ğŸ˜â€

On October 14, Lamb posted a video of the fall decor outside their Lamb & Co. storefront. She liked one fan's comment that said, â€œLooks great! Will you two be back on TV? I miss watching you!â€ She also liked when a fellow fan replied, â€œme too! I'm in withdrawals! ğŸ˜«â€

Davis, however, has primarly shared personal posts over the last several months, including chronicling her first trip overseas (to Denmark) this month and has not commented on or liked any inquiries about the show. 

Despite the lack of information about the future of â€œUnsellable Houses,â€ HGTV continues to regularly air reruns of the show. 

The show follows the twins as they help local homeowners update the houses they've had trouble selling. In a July 2024 episode of their â€œTwin Win Unfilteredâ€ podcast, the sisters said they never expected or sought out being on TV. 

Davis explained that their production company checked out their YouTube after being tipped off by a friend. She said, â€œA friend of ours, Gina, was approached about a TV show. She said â€˜no' for numerous reasons. Then she called us, and said, â€˜Hey, FYI, I gave your name to a production company because I think you guys would be good on a show.'â€

Title: â€˜Idol' Stars Shaken by Peer's Passing at 51: â€˜This Really Hurts'
Description:
The unexpected death of R&B icon D'Angelo on October 14, 2025, hit many of his peers in the music industry hard, including multiple â€œAmerican Idolâ€ stars, from Jennifer Hudson to Ruben Studdard, who shared their grief and shock via social media.

D'Angelo was a legendary R&B singer who helped pioneer the genre of music known as â€œneo-soul,â€ according to Variety. He died at age 51 following a private battle with pancreatic cancer. 

A statement issued by D'Angelo's family, per the Daily Mail, said, â€œThe shining star of our family has dimmed his light for us in this lifeâ€¦ After a prolonged and courageous battle with cancer, we are heartbroken to announce that Michael D'Angelo Archer, known to his fans around the world as D'Angelo, has been called home, departing this life today, October 14th, 2025.â€

A post shared by Jennifer Hudson (@iamjhud)

EGOT winner Jennifer Hudson, one of the most successful alumni in â€œAmerican Idolâ€ history, posted a photo of D'Angelo and wrote, â€œThis really hurts ! We lost a true original today. It just doesn't seem real!! It can't be . D'Angelo, your voice will live on forever. Rest well, King !!!â€

â€œName That Tuneâ€ co-host Randy Jackson, who was one of the original judges on â€œAmerican Idolâ€ when Hudson competed on the show, also shared his sadness over D'Angelo's passing. Jackson posted a video in his Instagram Stories of D'Angelo performing and wrote, â€œRest in power to an incredible legend ğŸ™ğŸ½â€

Also among the â€œAmerican Idolâ€ stars who shared their grief over D'Angelo's death were multiple â€œAmerican Idolâ€ winners, including season two champ Ruben Studdard. He posted a photo of the singer in his Instagram Stories and wrote, â€œThank you for all of the amazing music. RIP D'Angelo ğŸ¥ºğŸ¥ºğŸ¥ºâ€

Fantasia, who won the third season of â€œAmerican Idolâ€ â€” the same season in which Hudson took sixth place â€” posted a photo of D'Angelo in her Instagram Stories and wrote in large lettering, â€œNoooooo Way! ğŸ’”â€

Season 11 winner Phillip Phillips also posted a photo in his Instagram Stories of D'Angelo's â€œSpanish Jointâ€ single art and wrote, â€œNo words. Sad day for music. Genius. Inspirational. I've loved D'Angelos music for a long time. Rest well and thank you for inspiring so many all over the world.â€ 

Among other celebrities who publicly mourned D'Angelo's death on October 14 was BeyoncÃ©, who posted his photo on her website and, addressing him by his given name, wrote, â€œRest in peace, Michael Eugene Archer, known to the world of music as the inimitable D'Angelo. We thank you for your beautiful music, your voice, your proficiency on the piano, your artistry. You were the pioneer of neo-soul and that changed and transformed rhythm & blues forever. We will never forget you.â€

Actor Jamie Foxx posted a lengthy tribute to D'Angelo, which said in part, â€œGod put you here for a reason and we were all lucky enough to see what God had madeâ€¦ That's why today real tears run down my face â€¦ to hear the news that God has taken one of his special creations homeâ€¦ I know God doesn't make mistakesâ€¦ But this one hurts like hellâ€¦ rest up my friendâ€¦ you will be missed foreverâ€¦ But your music and your impression will be felt for generations to comeâ€

Thousands of fans also shared their grief on social media, including in response to posts from celebrities. On Hudson's tribute to D'Angelo, one person wrote, â€œOMG, I'm shocked, I'm learning this through your post â˜¹ï¸â˜¹ï¸â˜¹ï¸. I was learning to his songs earlier today, that's so sad, such a unique talent and voice !!! â˜¹ï¸âœ¨â€

â€œCannot believe this,â€ another commented. â€œRest in peace ğŸ˜¢â€

Title: Mark Ballas & Whitney Leavitt's DWTS Contemporary Dedication Dance
Description:
Tonight on â€œDancing with the Stars,â€ Whitney Leavitt and her professional partner Mark Ballas took the stage for a powerful â€œDedication Nightâ€ performance. Last week the couple performed a song from â€œHamiltonâ€ on Disney night. The pair danced a contemporary routine to â€œHealâ€ by Jamal Roberts, which Whitney dedicated to her husband, Connor. 

The heartfelt number followed a week of emotional challenges for Whitney, who recently opened up about having a mental breakdown while juggling motherhood, social media work, and her growing television presence.

A post shared by Dancing With The Stars #DWTS (@dancingwiththestars)

The performance starts off and finalizes with assistance from Whitney's husband Connor. The husband and wife moment caused tears in the ballroom, including a tearful statement by Carrie Ann. She complimented the performance by expressing how â€œdance was made for self-expressionâ€. 

Ballas and Leavitt receive a combined score of 33/40 for the night. Just one point behind Robert Irwin and Witney Carson.

Whitney revealed that rehearsing for Dedication Night pushed her to the edge. â€œI had a breakdown yesterday, a mental breakdown. But we made it,â€ she admitted, describing the experience as one filled with â€œblood, sweat and tearsâ€ reported The National Desk. She confessed that the demands of reality TV and influencer life left her feeling detached from herself but said, â€œI feel most like myself when I'm dancing.â€

A post shared by Whitney Leavitt (@whitleavitt)

Mark Ballas praised Whitney's ability to channel her emotions into movement, calling her â€œa fabulous mother and an excellent wifeâ€ while applauding her determination to keep going. The night became even more special when Whitney's husband, Connor, joined her and Mark on stage. Whitney shared that he had been rehearsing and couldn't wait to participate, adding, â€œHe tells us multiple times that he is so excited to get on the dance floor. So I cannot wait.â€ The performance gave audiences a rare look into the couple's deep connection and shared strength.

A post shared by Whitney Leavitt (@whitleavitt)

â€œDedication Nightâ€ is a Season 34 theme where each celebrity performs for someone meaningful in their life, often with that person joining the stage. Whitney and Mark's dance to â€œHealâ€ stood out among the evening's emotional performances. Other dedications included Andy Richter honoring his daughter, Robert Irwin paying tribute to his mother, and Scott Hoying dancing for his husband.

As one of the competition's top contenders, Whitney entered the night with high expectations. The emotional tone added an extra layer of intensity, particularly for Mark, who has been defending his choreography against critiques earlier this season. Despite the scrutiny, he maintained that his work fits within â€œDWTSâ€ standards and remains focused on authenticity.

Title: 'One Battle After Another' Junglepussy Q&A: This Scorpio Had Notes
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

If you're wondering what members of the French 75 chat about when they're not breaking immigrants out of detainment centers or robbing banks, the answer is astrology. Or at least that's what the cast of Paul Thomas Anderson's â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ discussed in between firing prop machine guns and driving getaway cars in the vigilante thriller.

â€œWe were all of us just there, chatting up in between takes, talking about astrology, talking about full moons,â€ Shayna McHayle, who plays French 75 member Junglepussy, told IndieWire. â€œTeyana [Taylor] was saying something about Scorpios, and I'm like, â€˜I'm a Scorpio,' and Leo[nardo DiCaprio]'s like, â€˜Yeah, I'm a Scorpio.' It was this whole thing.â€

 








Related Stories IndieWire's Future of Filmmaking to Partner with SCAD on Behind Their Lens Panels at Savannah Film Festival â€˜Blue Film' Review: A Disturbing Look at Pedophilia and Gay Shame Is Independent Cinema at Its Most Provocative 

For McHayle, spending time on the set of a blockbuster action film with A-list talent was quite surreal, and not something she sought out, but the experience was â€œwritten in the stars.â€ While she's previously appeared in two films, 2018's â€œSupport the Girlsâ€ and 2023's â€œThe Perfect Find,â€ she's predominantly a musician who raps under the stage name Junglepussy. After Anderson saw her on tour with Tame Impala in 2022, however, he was so inspired that he created a character, also named Junglepussy, just for McHayle.

 










â€œMy agent reached out to me like, â€˜Paul Thomas Anderson wants your number. Can I give it to him?' He wants to talk to you directly,â€ McHayle said. â€œI was like, â€˜Who? OK, yeah, give him my number.'â€

The pair then met several times in New York City over the next few years, with Anderson telling McHayle he was crafting a far-left vigilante based on her stage persona. 

â€œI didn't know that it was like Junglepussy for real until it really got close to locking in,â€ McHayle said. â€œHe gave me a hard copy of the script, and when I read it, I was like, â€˜What theâ€¦? What is this?' When I saw my name in there, and I saw my lyrics in there, and I just saw all these pussy references, I was gagged.â€

Even before shooting, however, astrology was a key topic of conversation. â€œTeyana's a Sag. Regina [Hall]'s a Sag. Alana [Haim]'s a Sag,â€ McHayle said. â€œOne day, me and Paul were texting before we started filming, and he thought I was a Sag too. He's like, â€˜Yeah, you know I got all these badass Sagittarius women in the French 75,' and I was like, â€˜Yeah, I'm a Scorpio.' He was like, â€˜OK, you're fired.'â€

After reading the â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ script, however, McHayle asked Anderson to make some changes to her character. â€œHe's writing and directing, so he wants to control everything,â€ she said, â€œBut I was just like, â€˜Paul, I am Junglepussy. This is me. I have to be Junglepussy after this movie. I was Junglepussy before this movie, and while I love the collaboration here that you're cooking up, I still have some non-negotiables.' There were things that I was like, â€˜OK, hard no on this. Junglepussy would never, like ever.'â€

 










Crafting a character that was a mix of her real-life persona and a fictional French 75 radical required some nuance from McHayle as an actor. â€œBecause he reached out to me directly, and was so inspired by my music, even â€˜This pussy don't pop for you,' having it like as a sign in the movie, which is how I've been performing it for the past decade, I knew there were a lot of things that he was drawn to, and I wanted to keep that part of me alive in the role,â€ she said. â€œBut I also wanted to do some things that I wouldn't usually do, like shooting a machine gun out of a moving vehicle, like robbing a bank.â€

McHayle channeled her stage persona while filming, especially during her instantly iconic bank robbery monologue. Walking across the tellers' counter amid the chaos of a stick-up, McHayle delivers a speech that serves both as a mission statement for the French 75 as well as a nod to Junglepussy's work. It's here that she tells the world, â€œThis pussy don't pop for you.â€ But filming in front of the entire cast and crew was daunting. 

â€œThat day, I just had to channel the same energy I bring to the stage whenever I do a big show,â€ she said. â€œI just had to channel that energy and do my thing.â€

McHayle is â€œstill gaggedâ€ at the magnitude of the film, and the stunts in particular. â€œThe stunts were scary,â€ she said, laughing, â€œLike the car chase scene, we were in the vehicles, like we were in it. When the minivan takes that hard left, we were in itâ€¦I'm not even, like, a rollercoaster kind of girl. I prefer a ride over a rollercoaster, but this was like a rollercoaster ride from hell.â€ 

 










â€œI know Warner Brothers didn't want to get in trouble with me,â€ she added about the movie's safety protocols. â€œI just had to let go and trust they knew what they were doing, because they know they have to keep us safe.â€

While â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ may only be McHayle's third movie, it's her second working with Regina Hall, whom she acted alongside in â€œSupport the Girls,â€ where they both played employees of a Hooters-esque establishment called Double Whammies. McHayle described the reunion as â€œa dream.â€ 

â€œShe is such a calming force,â€ McHayle gushes, â€œThe role she plays as Deandra [in â€˜One Battle After Another'] is just like steady, grounded. That's the literal energy she gives me when we work together on set. I just feel super calm around her. She's an OG, like that's my girl, just big sis vibes, like just super nurturing. I'm just like, â€˜Girl, I can't believe this is my second movie with you.' Love her for life.â€

McHayle is now manifesting a third Regina Hall collab and one â€œwith more screentime for both of us.â€ She's also rooting for Hall to earn an Oscar for her performance. â€œShe is truly such a force,â€ McHayle said. â€œI need her getting that Oscar. No pressure, but I want her to have it.â€ 

After filming wrapped in early 2024, McHayle had to wait patiently for over a year before she finally got to watch â€œOne Battle After Another.â€ She was invited to a private screening at the IMAX theater at New York's Lincoln Square AMC for a morning viewing. â€œIt was like me and some of the Christmas Adventurers, Tony Goldwyn and them,â€ she said. â€œWe're in this big-ass theater, and everybody's in their own row and taking it all in.â€ 

 










McHayle brought a coffee and a croissant and, during her first watch, was mostly just assessing how much of her work made the final cut. â€œI was there ticking my boxes,â€ she said. â€œLike I know what I did, and I know what I didn't do. Now let's see what's in here. When I saw all the pieces just remained, I was like, â€˜Oh, Paul is a real one. He was serious,' because you never know for real until it's done.â€

Since her first screening, where she admitted to being â€œover-caffeinatedâ€ and â€œoverstimulated,â€ she's seen the movie five more times, including in VistaVision. She's still â€œgaggedâ€ by the whole process, and knows there will be more to come. 

â€œFor some reason, whenever I do me, do my music, make my art, I'm attracting these opportunities,â€ she said. â€œI'm just staying super open to expanding my acting career, because it's obviously something I can't run from, hide from, like it just keeps popping up. I am going to surrender to the process and to the full spectrum of my gifts, my artistry, and just keep being me.â€ 

Hopefully, that means Shayna McHayle x Regina Hall 3.0 in the near future. 

â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ is now in theaters from Warner Bros. Pictures.

Title: This Film Residency Isn't Like All the Others
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Let this be a manifesto. Well, let it be a sort of manifesto. Let it be an essay, anyway. Let's write the thing and see how it goes. The right way to describe the project and our reasons behind it will reveal itself through process. Let's slow down. Let's open the windows. In the afternoon, the air from the windows is so soft and gentle. The crows are back, talking to the dog again, and the other birds are singing in the trees. They are all a part of this. The best way to write this would be to follow the principles of the thing itself. So let's start there with the windows open, in peace, in nature, and let's experiment.

 








Related Stories See Which Countries Have Submitted Films for Best International Feature at the 2026 Oscars The 2025 â€” 2026 Film Awards Calendar Stretches Out the Season 

We are JoÃ«le Walinga and Daniel Warth. We are a married couple. We are filmmakers. And we are the co-founders of a new residency called CASA PIP.

CASA PIP is a free residency that we've designed for filmmakers and filmworkers. Out in the mountains of Central Portugal, CASA PIP is a place where we hope people can come and work on their projects, or think through their ideas, play with something, experiment with something, read a damn book, look at the sky, swim in the river, write a script, experiment with light or color or sound, with motion, with time, draw something, rehearse something, lie down and rest, make lunch. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






In one full month at the residency, there are many opportunities to make lunch, and it just happens to be true that great ideas can be born while making lunch, just as they can while doing any of the above, or any other thing on the infinite list of human activities. We designed this place to let filmmakers be the artists and the individual humans that they are and work on whatever it is they need to work on in whatever way they think they need to work on it. We want to remove all the rules and the mentorships and the critiques and the guides and the script doctors and offer just a peaceful, free space for artists and their projects to blossom in their own particular, unique way.

CASA PIP was inspired in part by the generosity of our dear friend, Bruno Caetano, the impossibly humble animation filmmaker who, among his many impressive credits, produced the Academy Award-nominated short film â€œIce Merchants.â€ Bruno offered us the use of his family cottage in a tranquil Portuguese village for us to spend some time working on our screenplays. In his lovely cottage we sat, thinking, writing, lunching, amid the sound of goats chatting and the musical clanking of their bells, amid the sound of the breeze in the eucalyptus trees, amid the overwhelming aroma of those same trees, the humidity floating softly in the October air. There, in his house in the mountains eating chips, we wrote our scripts with confidence and inspiration, with a gushing-forth of ideas and an absence of external criticism that was unlike any other experience we'd had in the film industry.

 










Both of us have had our share of experience doing labs and residencies in various parts of the world, but we noticed a discrepancy between film residencies and the residencies offered to artists working in other forms. This form that we know and love, that we're so passionate about, just didn't seem to be treated very much like an art form. Film labs and residencies don't really encourage you to trust yourself as an artist. Rather, you are given guidance on what to change, how to shape your project to address external feedback or make it more market-standard.

We dreamed of a space where film is treated properly like an art form, where its makers are encouraged to play and think and experiment, a place where they could fail with pleasure, because so often we can find something amazing in our failure, something special, something that would otherwise never have been discovered. We wanted to offer a space that doesn't guide artists towards any particular outcome, but instead encourages them to trust their gut. And we wanted it to be free-of-charge, to invite artists across the economic spectrum, not just the ones with the independent means to afford a month's stay in Europe.

It is with this in mind that we launch CASA PIP, a free residency, open to anyone who works in any field of the film industry: writers, directors, actors, production designers, script supervisors, all are welcome. While we both know first-hand how much a writer and director can benefit from time and space to work in peace, without anyone looking over their shoulder, we believe that's also true about every other discipline in film. If we think of film as an art form, then all of the people who make films are artists. And we believe that every film would be incalculably richer if every single one of the people working on them had an opportunity to give just their part of it this kind of undivided attention and unsupervised experimentation.

 










So after years of holding this dream, at last, we have lovingly designed and furnished a small house in a remote and friendly village in the mountains of Central Portugal. Each selected resident will have the house to themselves, for free, for a period of up to one month. We have done our best to make this a space that is conducive to peace, inspiration, and experimentation. 

To select these residents, we have assembled an international jury. Jesse Cumming is the associate curator of the Wavelengths program at TIFF, as well as having programmed for Hot Docs, MoMA, Anthology Film Archives, and ICA London. Ana David is the official program advisor to Berlinale, and programs for Oslo/Fusion, BFI London Film Festival, and Queer Lisboa. Winnie Wang is the winner of both the International Documentary Association's 2022 Getting Real Fellowship and the Toronto Film Critics' Association's 2024 Emerging Critic Award, and is an industry programmer at TIFF. These three will review all applications and make their decisions by the end of January 2026.

We are excited to be opening our doors to the public and launching our call for submissions in October, almost exactly two years after our stay at our friend Bruno's cottage. In fact, we are in the residency house now, writing this essay in between putting the last touches on the decoration and the design. We can confirm that the crows have now left. A rooster just â€¦ howled? It's time for lunch.

 










CASA PIP opens for applications on Wednesday, October 15. Residencies begin in 2026. For more information and to apply, please visit: www.casapip.com 

JoÃ«le Walinga is an award-winning Canadian visual artist and filmmaker. She is an alumna of the 2021 Berlin International Film Festival's talent development program Berlinale Talents, and the 2022 Zurich Film Festival Academy. Her work has been shown at the Art Gallery of Ontario, SXSW, International Short Film Festival Oberhausen, Gallery 44 Centre for Contemporary Photography, RIDM, and Ji.hlava International Documentary Film Festival among others. Her most recent feature film â€œSelf-Portraitâ€ premiered at the SXSW Film Festival in 2022, won the Special Jury Prize at RIDM, and was released on MUBI. The film was a New York Times pick for films to stream in spring 2024. Walinga is the founder of Toronto-based film and video art production company Soft Studio, and the co-creator of the free filmmaking gear program Everyone's Camera and the free filmmaker residency program CASA PIP. 

Daniel Warth is an award-winning Portuguese-Canadian screenwriter and film director. His first narrative feature Dim the Fluorescents won the Grand Jury Award at the Slamdance Film Festival and was called â€œOne of the Year's Strongest Debutsâ€ by The New York Times. His first documentary â€œUntold Hoursâ€ screened at Toronto International Film Festival and BAFICI, and is currently streaming on MUBI. Daniel was one of eight international screenwriters selected to participate in Toronto International Film Festival's 2022 Writers' Studio program with his upcoming feature film â€œEnduring,â€ starring Katherine Waterston, which Daniel is co-producing with two-time Palme D'Or-winning producer GeneviÃ¨ve Lemal. In 2025, Daniel co-founded the free filmmaker residency CASA PIP in Celavisa, Portugal.

Title: â€˜Blue Film' Review: A Disturbing Look at Pedophilia and Gay Shame Is Independent Cinema at Its Most Provocative
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Few contemporary films about unresolved childhood abuse â€” which is always unresolved, in the end, anyway â€” cut as narrowly close to the bone as Elliot Tuttle's two-hander masked as provocation, â€œBlue Film.â€ 

Rejected by mainstream film festivals before it premiered in Edinburgh this summer and NewFest in New York in October, this taboo-busting study of a masculine camboy confronted by the pedophile teacher who many years ago desired him holds back little and offers even less that's palatable to swallow. Its limitations as a stagelike piece aside, the movie wrings emotional complexity from a fraught, ever-shifting dialogue between a convicted child abuser and the student, now a late twenties sex worker, he spared.

 








Related Stories See Which Countries Have Submitted Films for Best International Feature at the 2026 Oscars The 2025 â€” 2026 Film Awards Calendar Stretches Out the Season 

â€œBlue Film,â€ which takes place entirely in a rented Hancock Park Airbnb in Los Angeles with only two actors, dares to go places I have not seen an American movie travel to in a while. There was an Israeli movie called â€œPrincessâ€ at Sundance in 2014, directed by Tali Shalom Ezer, which freaked a lot of people out. It was about a 12-year-old girl's â€œclose relationshipâ€ with her mother's boyfriend. There was the 2011 Austrian movie â€œMichael,â€ directed by Michael Haneke protÃ©gÃ© Markus Schleinzer, about an insurance salesman sexually abusing the 10-year-old boy locked up in his basement. These were shocking. Neither were American.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






Tuttle, an American filmmaker himself who received support on the project from Mark Duplass of all possible collaborators, is willing to take you to those same dark places, ones that remind you of European directors who want to shake you with their frank psychosexual provocations. It's impressive where Tuttle, this second-time feature filmmaker, goes with his surprisingly humanistic and empathetic approach to material about abuse. One where a pedophile teacher's sexual fantasy about his former student's talent show performance emerges as oddly wistful.

â€œBlue Filmâ€ stars rising actor Kieron Moore as dom camboy Aaron Eagle (whose real name is Alex McConnell) opposite Reed Birney as his estranged middle school teacher, who reconnect over one night filled with conversations about desire, shame, and guilt. I'm not surprised festivals, allegedly such as Sundance and SXSW, looked away from it. Mainstream audiences will be alienated by this unapologetic exploration of quote-unquote aberrant sexuality, but those looking for a challenge in the vein of â€˜90s films from Todd Solondz or Gregg Araki will feel seen in Tuttle's exploration of how abuse warps memory, and memory warps accounts of abuse.

In asking you to feel sorry for a pedophile while making a gay man his scene partner, â€œBlue Filmâ€ dances on the tricky line from early abuse to later-in-life sexual behavior. When the movie begins, we see Aaron (Moore), sweaty and hairy in white briefs and tattooed top-to-toe, putting on a live stream for his submissive followers. One of his anonymous fans offers $50,000 for an in-person meet-and-greet. Financially desperate, he agrees to spend the night with the client, who greets him sheathed in a balaclava with the promise of even more money and perhaps pizza if Aaron is willing to open up about himself.

 










That client, it turns out, is Mr. Grant, aka Hank, Aaron's long-ago teacher, and one who took a special interest in Aaron as a child. Some time while Aaron was in school, Hank was intercepted sexually assaulting a child on campus, was fired from his job, and received a prison sentence. With the mask off and Aaron stripped down yet again, their walls start to come down. Hank, he reveals, has now turned to religion as an atonement for his own torment, but his search for meaning has not been without other attempts at or contemplations of assaulting kids, as he tells Aaron.

Tuttle's script and camera pass no judgment on the characters, like when Aaron shares a bone-chilling story of childhood abuse while naked in a bathtub that may or may not be true, or when Hank also offers a sickening recounting of molestation he endured at the hands of a relative. The actors are as game as any you could imagine, working from a script that you can imagine a lot of people said â€œhell noâ€ to.

Birney, 71, and best known for work in television and theater (â€œThe Humansâ€), invites you to feel all his hurt, even as his world is a morally disturbed one we are made to live inside for the movie's running time. As Aaron, Moore, meanwhile, conceals deep wounds of his own, while also high on the power imbalance this situation has tipped his way, where Hank wants to know if he â€œstill lovesâ€ Aaron. Another wrinkle is that the camera certainly wants us to also desire Moore, who is often next to naked, placing us at least adjacent to Hank's gaze.

 










Hank is also curious about whether he can still be attracted to adult whom he once desired as a child. He shaves Aaron head to toe to make him look more physically childlike in one of the film's queasier implications. What these two actors take on is undeniably brave, even as the movie tilts toward becoming suffocating, which is intentional. â€œBlue Filmâ€ is confined to a single environment, after all.

Cinematographer Ryan Jackson-Healy also shot the equally controversy-starting, Birney-led film â€œMass,â€ about the ramifications of a school shooting for the parents affected. The DP knows his way around a tight room with just a few people, and the visual beauty of this movie (indeed, often cloaked in literal blues as night turns to dawn) helps alleviate the agonies on display.

Tuttle wisely avoids flashbacks or out-of-this-room context. We are stuck with these two people and our discomfort with them, even though we might also feel tenderness toward them. â€œBlue Filmâ€ nudges at a lot of tricky issues, like the question of whether being gay in the present day is somehow the result of inflictions of the past. And the parallel to that question is whether abuse can also beget more abuse, i.e. make you into a pedophile or sex offender. Hank says he knew who he was once his sexual fantasies in middle school, about his fellow same-age classmates, remained the same into adulthood. What Tuttle wants to attack here is this terrible fork-in-the-road notion that pedophilia and homosexuality stem from the same root.

 










Still, â€œBlue Filmâ€ does the rare work of listening with compassion to a pedophile such as Hank, and as an audience, you can either be curious about that or just let it make you uncomfortable. Hank is tormented by who he is, as is Aaron, but they are not the same person, and they did not come from the same place. â€œBlue Filmâ€ leaves you feeling a little bit ill, and very uneasy about how you're supposed to feel. But when most films either wouldn't dare go here at all, or would tell you how to feel about the material, that's rare and welcome.

â€œBlue Filmâ€ premiered at the Edinburgh Film Festival and NewFest. It is currently seeking U.S. distribution.

Want to stay up to date on IndieWire's film reviews and critical thoughts? Subscribe here to our newly launched newsletter, In Review by David Ehrlich, in which our Chief Film Critic and Head Reviews Editor rounds up the best new reviews and streaming picks along with some exclusive musings â€” all only available to subscribers.

Title: IndieWire's Future of Filmmaking to Partner with SCAD on Behind Their Lens Panels at Savannah Film Festival
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

The 2025 SCAD Savannah Film Festival is just around the corner, and this year's event will feature more than just a selection of the fall's biggest films. IndieWire's Future of Filmmaking is proud to partner with SCAD for â€œBehind Their Lens,â€ a series of three panels moderated by IndieWire editors featuring the artists who helped make some of the films gracing the festival's screens. The panels will publish on IndieWire in the days afterward.

IndieWire Editorial Director Kate Erbland will moderate the â€œBehind Their Lens: Artisansâ€ panel, which celebrates prominent below-the-line female artisans. Panelists will include â€œThe Secret Agentâ€ and â€œThe Balconettesâ€ cinematographer Evgenia Alexandrova; â€œHim,â€ â€œRez Ball,â€ â€œEcho,â€ and â€œ13thâ€ cinematographer Kira Kelly; â€œSpringsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere,â€ â€œKing Richard,â€ and â€œThe Fighterâ€ editor Pamela Martin; â€œHim,â€ â€œIdiotka,â€ and â€œThe Madnessâ€ editor Taylor Joy Mason; and â€œSinners,â€ â€œIronheart,â€ and â€œAtlantaâ€ hair designer Shunika Terry.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories â€˜Blue Film' Review: A Disturbing Look at Pedophilia and Gay Shame Is Independent Cinema at Its Most Provocative See Which Countries Have Submitted Films for Best International Feature at the 2026 Oscars 

IndieWire VP, Features Strategy and host of the Filmmaker Toolkit podcast Chris O'Falt will moderate â€œBehind Their Lens: Directorsâ€ and â€œBehind Their Lens: Producers,â€ two panels highlighting some of the most successful female filmmakers working today. â€œBehind Their Lens: Directorsâ€ will feature â€œIf I Had Legs I'd Kick Youâ€ director Mary Bronstein, â€œThe Acolyteâ€ creator and â€œRussian Dollâ€ co-creator Leslye Headland, â€œRental Familyâ€ director HIKARI, and â€œSorry Babyâ€ director Eva Victor.

 










â€œBehind Their Lens: Producersâ€ features â€œSpringsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere,â€ â€œWendell & Wild,â€ and â€œThe Maze Runnerâ€ producer Ellen Goldsmith-Vein; â€œLes MisÃ©rables,â€ â€œGood Grief,â€ and â€œBridget Jones's Diaryâ€ producer Debra Hayward; â€œReality,â€ â€œThe Guilty,â€ and â€œBeasts of No Nationâ€ producer Riva Marker; â€œBack to Black,â€ â€œGhosts,â€ and â€œElizabethâ€ producer Alison Owen; and â€œFatal Followingâ€ and â€œAll for Herâ€ producer Kaila York. 

The 2025 SCAD Savannah Film Festival runs from October 25 through November 1. 

All â€œBehind Their Lensâ€ panels will be held in the Gutstein Gallery, with â€œBehind Their Lens: Artisansâ€ taking place at 2:30 p.m. on Monday, October 27, â€œBehind Their Lens: Producersâ€ at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, October 28 and â€œBehind Their Lens: Directorsâ€ following at 2:30 p.m. ET. Tickets to all three panels can be purchased on the SCAD Savannah Film Festival website.

And check back here in the days after to watch the full panels.

Title: PinkPantheress: Fancy Some More? Album Review
Description:
7.6

Genre:

Pop/R&B / Electronic

Label:

Warner UK

Reviewed:

October 15, 2025

Some say that, when King Arthur pulled Excalibur from the stone, it marked him as the sovereign ruler of Britain. It's hard not to feel the same way about PinkPantheress when she samples Underworld's â€œDark & Longâ€ or â€œRomeoâ€ by Basement Jaxx, or lets out a â€œWow, wow, wow!â€ at the end of her surprise summer hit â€œIllegalâ€ like she's the second coming of Cassie from Skins. Pink, along with Oasis and Olivia Dean, has made British identity chic again this year, maybe for the first time since Alexa Chung released her iconic It book more than a decade ago. If you need proof, listen to Bladee's verse on his new remix of Pink's â€œStateside,â€ in which the Swedish musician shouts out regions of the UK like he's DJ Pharris dropping Chicago references on â€œCold:â€ Midlands, Highlands, Sussex, Yorkshire, Croydon, Knightsbridgeâ€¦

Such is Pink's power: Since releasing her second mixtape, Fancy That, in May, the 24-year-old has proven she has a preternatural ability to make the most outrÃ©-normie references feel like they're on the bleeding edge of cool. Her Glastonbury set was introduced by Louis Theroux and possessed what my friend described as a â€œBritain's Got Talent aesthetic,â€ and it was one of the festival's best. Fans affectionately read Pink's style, but none of them have a bag collaboration with Diane V and Dover Street Market, do they? Fancy Some More?, Pink's new Fancy That remix project, doesn't have the ultraconceptual bent of Charli XCX's Brat remix project from last year, but it moves with the same swagger: Like, who else would have the cheek, ingenuity, and clout to gather all these people under one roof?

Fancy Some More?'s remixes are split into two discs, one featuring vocalists and the other producers. (The release also includes a third disc, featuring the original tape.) Scanning the guest list is, I imagine, what it's like to flick through Pink's iPod. On the vocalist side, you have K-pop stars (SEVENTEEN and Yves from LOONA) alt-pop it girls (Oklou, Rachel Chinouriri, Ravyn Lenae, Bladee), and centrist stars with underground clout (Zara Larsson, JADE, Kylie Minogue, JT, Sugababes). The producer disc mostly features artists who bore clear influence on Fancy That (Basement Jaxx, Groove Armada, Joe Goddard) alongside upstart locals (Nia Archives, Leod, Kilimanjaro) and also Kaytranada, seemingly kept on retainer by the major labels for any remixing needs. The project is rounded out by a coterie of Braziliansâ€”Anitta, DJ Caio Prince, Adame DJ, and Mochakkâ€”which, with any luck, signals the sound of future PinkPantheress music.

The vast majority of these remixes totally bang, and many of them serve the function of wish fulfillment. Have you (like me) ever wanted â€œIllegalâ€ to feel even faster and more disorienting? Nia Archives, London's premiere young junglist, makes the whole song feel like a 90-degree drop on a rollercoaster. Have you been scouring SoundCloud for a mashup of â€œStatesideâ€ with its spiritual forebear, Kylie Minogue's â€œSlowâ€? Here's la grand dame herself whispering â€œAre you ready for me?â€ and eliciting goosebumps when she sings â€œNever met an Aussie girl, you say.â€ The sky seems to crack wide open when the Sugababes drop into â€œNice to Know Youâ€ and provide a hi-fi rendition of the hook Pink sampled on the original version of the track.

The most effective remixes flip the original songs on their head: Basement Jaxx turn â€œTonight,â€ one of the least dance-forward tracks on Fancy That, into a throbbing, shimmery big-room banger, its five-minute runtime practically begging for a 12â€ version. Meanwhile, Caio Prince and Adame traverse baile funk, Miami bass, and fight-ready big beat on their flip of the previously lightweight â€œStars.â€ Oklou drags the Basement Jaxx sample on â€œGirl Like Meâ€ as far out of its original context as she can take it, making the liberated refrain of â€œLet it all goâ€ sound less like dancefloor hedonism and more like a desperate attempt to get over a lingering heartbreak.

With the exception of Kaytranada's â€œGirl Like Meâ€â€”which sounds roughly the same as every other Kaytranada remix in recent memoryâ€”it feels like all these tracks were made with a level of care uncommon for a major label remix album, which so often feel easy cash grabs or attempts to prolong an album cycle that's running out of steam. Fancy Some More? feels like a rowdy, well-earned celebration and reaffirms the main ideas PinkPantheress has gestured toward for much of the year: Heavy reference doesn't inherently go hand-in-hand with a lack of ingenuity. Successive generations of dance producers don't have to be at war with each other. Pop music, done right, can feel like the key to a world that's smarter, more free, and way more fun.

Title: Madison Cunningham: Ace Album Review
Description:
7.5

Genre:

Folk/Country

Label:

Verve Forecast

Reviewed:

October 15, 2025

Over the past few years, California-based singer and multi-instrumentalist Madison Cunningham has become an industry darling for her virtuosic guitar playing. She's quietly ubiquitous: opening for Hozier and Harry Styles, appearing on albums by Lucius and Mumford & Sons, performing with Sara Bareilles and Chris Thile, and recording a Buckingham Nicks covers album with Andrew Bird. Her rÃ©sumÃ© may be highly NPR-friendly, but her work is often genuinely challenging. Her 2022 song â€œIn From Japanâ€ is a solid example of Cunningham's capabilities as a songwriter and guitarist: a lightly psychedelic, heavily syncopated 7/4 ballad that's delightfully inside-baseball about the commodification of music. â€œWatermark/They're trying to own the image nature carved/Well, metadata won't support your cause,â€ she sings. She fully came into her own on her second studio album, the Grammy-winning album Revealer, made in 2022 with a team of industry veterans like Matt Chamberlain, Dan Wilson, and Mike Elizondo.

Shortly after Revealer's success, Cunningham met Prince's former guitarist, Wendy Melvoin.  â€œYou have something to say, and you aren't saying it yet,â€ Melvoin told her, and played her Martha Wainwright's confrontational classic â€œBloody Mother Fucking Asshole.â€ Months later, Cunningham divorced her husband of five years (she'd known him since they were teens in church) and ditched her guitar for a piano-based album indebted to Joni Mitchell's Blue (she'd previously recorded a cover of â€œCaliforniaâ€). As with Cunningham's other music, the lush presentation of Ace disguises unexpected chord changes and unconventional time signatures. Here, it's a perfect strategy for a record about the disintegration of a seemingly perfect relationship. The orchestral arrangements, by Cunningham, yMusic's Rob Moose, Philip Krohnengold, and Mercury Rev's Jesse Chandler, often approach Joanna Newsom territory, something Cunningham hasn't tried before. While Ace is quieter and less accessible than her past work, it's just as musically sophisticated, with newfound chamber-pop grandeur.

Cunningham is a classic â€œmusician's musician,â€ her songs dense with time signature hops and jazzy voicings. Even the earthy acoustic song â€œWakeâ€ comes with an uneasy melody, with Fleet Foxes' Robin Pecknold's offering dissonant harmonies that sound like a worn-out Simon & Garfunkel vinyl wavering in pitch. And there's a lot of grief and animosity simmering underneath even Ace's quieter songs.On â€œSkeletree,â€ Cunningham teases, â€œSomething's got to giveâ€ over a dense groove, until she finally shouts, â€œI don't trust what you say/But I've come to lose my faith in everyoneâ€ as the trembling strings and electric guitars finally break through.

The album's central theme is one of untangling yourself from someone else, particularly after anger and betrayal. Cunningham doesn't go into specifics, but her lyrics are loaded anyway. On â€œMy Full Name,â€ she sings, â€œYour brother only shares your family shame/But he doesn't really know youâ€; on â€œMummy,â€ she sings, â€œI'm the oldest of five/The first to be torn/In your mother's eyes/You were the firstbornâ€â€”a line with enough baggage to outfit an entirely different song. â€œMummyâ€ sounds like a whimsical lullaby, or one of Regina Spektor's artsier moments, but it contains some of Cunningham's most incisive lyrics. First she blames herselfâ€”â€œI never could explain myself, the hurt that I feel, the hurt that I causeâ€â€”then she turns the same words against an ex. The truth of what actually happened feels deliberately out of reach, much like a partner can â€œknow every mole and skin tagâ€ (â€œTake Twoâ€) and still not actually understand their lover.

Ace is the work of a mature, controlled songwriter. The album largely avoids the clichÃ©s of the divorce postmortem, earning its more plainspoken lines like, â€œSome days I hate you so much/I want you back.â€ Even when the music is more conventional, Cunningham fits in a cutting lineâ€”as on the very '70s soft-rock â€œBeyond that Moon,â€ where she sings, â€œI'd stay under your skin if I were convinced that there were room.â€ Only lead single â€œMy Full Nameâ€  keeps things a little too simple, lacking the complex sentiments and intricate arrangements that make this album special. Ace rewards close listening; from a stately chamber-folk album, something quietly unrelenting emerges.
